text: Rob,  Thanks for a very interesting article: I'm looking forward to more in this series. I've been following the development of RavenDB on Ayende's blog, but in his hurry to talk about cool stuff, he often omits basics like walkthroughs!

Rob Ashton has been exploring the Raven DB project created by Ayende, outlining his initial thoughts on the project in this post, and goes deeper into the getting started topics in his next post ‘RavenDB - An Introduction‘
Thank you for submitting this cool story - Trackback from progg.ru
Excellent writeup and topic choice, thanks.
Pleased to be of service :) [Always nice to get feedback like that as well as questions!]

I'm having a strange problem. Just the first basic example, up to the point where you call SaveChanges() for the first time, I can't even get past that point. The project won't build. It says that the namespace 'Raven' could not be found. It's strange because I added the reference, I added the using directive, and DocumentStore even shows up in IntelliSense (along with all the other RavenDB specific types). There are no errors (no squiggly lines) that show up. It only doesn't work when I select 'build'.I referenced all the dlls in the Raven.Client build, as you said. Is there something I'm missing?
Check the target runtime of your project, you'll want to reference .NET Framework 4, not .NET Framework 4 Client Profile (or whatever else your default might be)
Thanks for the fast response! Yes, that worked. Of course it was something simple! (Yes, the default was set to .NET 4 Client Profile)Thank you,--Alex
The advantage for everybody else of me being as egotistical as I am, is that I check my comment's *way too often* :)
How do I store a DataTable to RavenDB? A DataTable doesn't correspond to a class.  I believe MongoDB lets you create generic documents with key/value pairs.
The short answer is you probably wouldn't.The long answer is I believe that some support is being added for custom serialization/de-serialization so that scenario is very much possible.
This is helping me a ton.  Thanks!
wow, this is really great.. I am looking forward to use raven db in my next projects.
I like the way you do things at this website.
